When the potential punishment is more severe, the perceived cost of committing a crime increases, which reduces the likelihood of the crime being committed in the first place. The death penalty, being the most severe form of punishment, carries the ultimate consequence—loss of life—which naturally carries a stronger deterrent effect than a sentence of life in prison, where the criminal still exists, albeit in confinement.

This is especially true for individuals who may not perceive the long-term consequences of their actions or who are influenced by peer behavior and the threat of legal repercussions.

In short, the death penalty serves as a more potent deterrent than life imprisonment because it represents the most severe and irreversible consequence. The data and theory both support the idea that the death penalty, when applied appropriately and in a fair legal system, plays a crucial role in reducing violent crime.
